div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin June 23 1916
div1.p: Your last letter was very sweet and exceptionally welcome. It seems such a long time since I’d heard from you.
As you know by this time poor, fine, old Chapman is gone. He was the best and bravest of us all and his death has been a terrible blow to all of us.

There were but a few who went out this afternoon. Five in all, because yesterday we had a number of smashes, I for one. I had landed and was on the field when Rumsey came swooping down and hit me. Both of our machines were injured. Then after that there was an alert and three more broke on landing in the dusk. The five that went out got mixed up in a fight over the German lines against superior numbers. Chapman fought furiously. After the combat he was not to be seen. Another escadrille was out and a pilot from it signaled a Nieuport he had seen fall. Chapman was late but we thought he had landed at a field near by in order to visit Balsley. He had put a sack (over)
of oranges in his machine to take to Balsley after the evening sortie had finished. I remember discussing the wind with Victor just before he left as he wanted to decide on the best way to land at the field. Then he asked me if I could see the other machines above circling for the start. That was the last I saw of the poor boy. Finally after we had called up all the aviation fields around an observer of a German plane phoned in. He was flying very high and had seen the fight. He reported that he had seen a Nieuport head downwards, go into a cork-screw and that the wings had folded up and the machine dropped like a stone into the German lines.

I liked Victor better than anyone in the escadrille — about the same as Bill Thaw — and I feel rotten about his death. He was an exceptional man from every stand point and a pilot that was as skilful [sic] and as brave as any in the war. He was charming all the way thru [sic] and some how it was just like him to have been killed while he was taking oranges to a wounded
comrade.

I’m glad you are having your vacation and happy to know that its so long. Be sure and keep me posted on the dates you are to be out of Paris for I do not want to have my “permission” fall at that time. Its going to be so nice to see you again, Marcelle. Its going to seem even better than when I came back after the Ambulance work for this business is so much more serious.
Paul has moved again. This time to 80 Rue Boissiere as you doubtless know.
I’m sorry to hear our Russian friend is ill. Queer to have scarlet fever at her age, isn’t it?
You’ve probably seen Walter by this time and he being so much finer that the rest of us you’ll forget me and I won’t have any letters for awhile. xxx

The phone has just rung. The Direction has phoned that Balsley is dying. It is an awful shame. I have waked up the Captain and Kiffin and we are going over to see him. It is raining and late and it seems to make it more horrible. The
poor boy.
Kiffin says to give you his best. He’s not the time to write but means well just the same.
We won’t be back until 3 in the morning but we’ve a sortie soon after.

closer.seg:
June 24th.
Queer we found Balsley better instead of worse. Had blow outs and things and didn’t return until 5. A.M. Fortunately it was cloudy and we made no sortie.
